The lighting effect on Straus'
Field for the after-dark practices
has been greatly improved by the
addition of two arc lights on the
west side of the field. The necessity for these lights has long been
felt, but the "powers that he" at
Hopkins had delayed installing
this necessary illumination because of the expense involved.

expenses of the installation of the
lights. His offer was accepted and
the improvement, which is very
noticeable, has excited the gratitude of the entire squad.

SOFT PEDAL,THERE!
Towards the close of this week there will be inaugurated by Hopkins men a series of parades, bonfires, stunts, etc., by which the participants will endeavor to inform the city of Baltimore—and St.
John's—that there is a Hopkins-St. John's game at Homewood Saturday.
"Pep" is the watchword;"pep" is desired. With this "pep", however, should be mingled a certain amount of moderation, of selfrestraint. It should be remembered at all times that the parade and
bonfire are Hopkins activities, the participants Hopkins men, and that
the University will be judged by our actions on these occasions.

MURAD
THE TURKISH CIGARETTE

DO YOU REMEMBER?
Do you remember the lump in your throat when the first regiment entrained for France? Do you remember the thrill of victory
when that regiment came marching home to the tune of martial
bands, to the plaudits of cheering throngs? Perhaps you joined step
with them. Perhaps you too had been across. At any rate, you saw
and welcomed them.
But, do you remember those who could not keep step with the
marching hundreds, those who rode in motor cars—because somewhere on a foreign battlefield wounds were received which made it
impossible for the heroes, though stout of heart, to join that triumphant procession?
And do you remember the files of marching women who came
home after the Armistice was signed, the brave, heroic ones, who in
field and base hospitals nursed back to life wounded ones of the
Argonne, of Verdun, and of Chateau Thierry ?
If you do remember you cannot forget that it is YOUR duty
NOW to think first of those who formed the first line of defense. It
your privilege to see that those men who could not march, who
can not even now be fitted into the old vocations, be made strong
enough to work once more and be trained into new pursuits. It is
also your privilege to keep intact the army of nurses that the recovery
of the disabled men may be as rapid as possible.
The American Red Cross is helping point the way to this readjustment of the lives of the wounded soldiers, sailors and marines.
The Fifth Annual Roll Call—November 11 to 24—is the means by
which you can help. The membership fee is $1. Your subscription is
needed.—From the "Trinity Tripod."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1921
DRAMATIC CLUB REHEARSING
ONE-ACT PLAYS

The three one-act plays to be
produced by the Dramatic Club
early in December are now under
rehearsal. The casts which were
announced in a former issue of the
News-Letter are
particularly
eager to make these plays a success, as upon their success or failure depends their collegiate dramatic future.
Gilson Engel, president of the
Dramatic Club, has appointed Eli
Frank, Jr., chairman of the committee in charge of the plays. He
will be assisted by Henry West,
Who will coach Philip Moeller's
Play, "A Roadhouse in Arden,"
and "Joe" Moran, who will coach
his own play. Moran has yet to
choose the cast for his play, but
he intends to do this shortly.
Frank will coach the tragedy,"A
Death in Fever Flat" himself.
The scenery will be designed
Under the direction of Mariano
Bacilli°. The plays are especially
well adapted to being produced
in the Bohemian atmosphere the
club has created in their studio.
The style of the scenery will be
modern.

PREACHERS' CLUB SELECTS
OFFICERS FOR YEAR

In November, 1920, a group of
Freshmen got together and
formed an association afterwards
known as the "Preachers' Club."
They were assisted in their organization by Pierce Hays, then
Y1 M. C. A. secretary. Their primary object in forming the organization was to bring to the attention of the University authorities the need of such courses as
New Testament Study and Hebrew, for clerical students and
ministers who could devote a few
hours a day to this purpose.
In the last part of the year it
Was definitely decided to carry on
this organization. A constitution
Was drawn up and adopted. According to this constitution, the
Purpose of the club is to promote
friendship and to interest all students in religious life work.
Meetings are to be held every
second and last Monday of each
month. If possible, a prominent
Speaker will be secured for the
first meeting of each month. The
second meeting will be given over
to discussion of the talk of the previous week.
The officers for this year are:
President, Paul Stevens; vicepresident, Kendig Wallace; secretary, Paul Silvester ; treasurer,
Wheeler.
A meeting will be held this
Monday night. The Rev. Dr. William S. Hammond will give a talk
On "John Wesley and His Place
Among the Great Christians."

Shallenberger's Meter-1888

Single-Phase Meter-1921

Oliver B.Shallenberger
T IS ONE THING to produce a new idea
I that is simply of theoretical interest. It is
another to make the new idea into a commercial success.

I

This is the story of Oliver B. Shallenberger,
and how in 1888 he discovered the principle
that led him to invent the watt-hour meter,
the familiar little device that makes practicable
the commercial distribution of alternating current, which means 95% of all the electricity
that is distributed.
Shallenberger, who resigned a Naval commission to take up his work with Westinghouse,
made his discovery while experimenting with
a newly devised alternating current arc lamp.
His attention was attracted by the behavior of
a small spring which had fallen upon the main
magnet of the lamp, into such a position that
the forces proceeding from both the magnet
coil and the extended soft iron core affected it.
And the simple little thing that he noticed was
merely that the spring was slowly rotating! But
to the intelligently curious observer, that was
• enough.
Further experiments having satisfied him that
the action was caused by alternating electric

currents, he set to work, encouraged by his
knowledge of Westinghouse policies, to make
practical the newly found principle. Three weeks
of almost uninterrupted toil, and he had produced the first practical alternating current
meter of the induction type—the universal type
of the present time.
Thus for the first time the measurement of the
quantity of alternating current passing through
a line was made commercially practicable and
its distribution became possible from an economic
as well as an engineering point of view. In fact,
the whole structure of our great power systems
depends upon the accurate measurement, by
millions of such meters, of the electricity used
in the homes and industries of the nation. So
well was Shallenberger's work done, and so
complete was his conception of the possibilities
of his discovery, that for more than thirty years
his fundamental idea has been in use in many
and various forms.
The encouragement which Westinghouse has
always given to new ideas, and the judgment
with which they have been evaluated, are
nowhere better exemplified than in this story of
the alternating current meter.

MURAD
THE TURKISH CIGARETTE

DO YOU REMEMBER?
Do you remember the lump in your throat when the first regiment entrained for France? Do you remember the thrill of victory
when that regiment came marching home to the tune of martial
bands, to the plaudits of cheering throngs? Perhaps you joined step
with them. Perhaps you too had been across. At any rate, you saw
and welcomed them.
But, do you remember those who could not keep step with the
marching hundreds, those who rode in motor cars—because somewhere on a foreign battlefield wounds were received which made it
impossible for the heroes, though stout of heart, to join that triumphant procession?
And do you remember the files of marching women who came
home after the Armistice was signed, the brave, heroic ones, who in
field and base hospitals nursed back to life wounded ones of the
Argonne, of Verdun, and of Chateau Thierry ?
If you do remember you cannot forget that it is YOUR duty
NOW to think first of those who formed the first line of defense. It
your privilege to see that those men who could not march, who
can not even now be fitted into the old vocations, be made strong
enough to work once more and be trained into new pursuits. It is
also your privilege to keep intact the army of nurses that the recovery
of the disabled men may be as rapid as possible.
The American Red Cross is helping point the way to this readjustment of the lives of the wounded soldiers, sailors and marines.
The Fifth Annual Roll Call—November 11 to 24—is the means by
which you can help. The membership fee is $1. Your subscription is
needed.—From the "Trinity Tripod."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1921
DRAMATIC CLUB REHEARSING
ONE-ACT PLAYS

The three one-act plays to be
produced by the Dramatic Club
early in December are now under
rehearsal. The casts which were
announced in a former issue of the
News-Letter are
particularly
eager to make these plays a success, as upon their success or failure depends their collegiate dramatic future.
Gilson Engel, president of the
Dramatic Club, has appointed Eli
Frank, Jr., chairman of the committee in charge of the plays. He
will be assisted by Henry West,
Who will coach Philip Moeller's
Play, "A Roadhouse in Arden,"
and "Joe" Moran, who will coach
his own play. Moran has yet to
choose the cast for his play, but
he intends to do this shortly.
Frank will coach the tragedy,"A
Death in Fever Flat" himself.
The scenery will be designed
Under the direction of Mariano
Bacilli°. The plays are especially
well adapted to being produced
in the Bohemian atmosphere the
club has created in their studio.
The style of the scenery will be
modern.

PREACHERS' CLUB SELECTS
OFFICERS FOR YEAR

In November, 1920, a group of
Freshmen got together and
formed an association afterwards
known as the "Preachers' Club."
They were assisted in their organization by Pierce Hays, then
Y1 M. C. A. secretary. Their primary object in forming the organization was to bring to the attention of the University authorities the need of such courses as
New Testament Study and Hebrew, for clerical students and
ministers who could devote a few
hours a day to this purpose.
In the last part of the year it
Was definitely decided to carry on
this organization. A constitution
Was drawn up and adopted. According to this constitution, the
Purpose of the club is to promote
friendship and to interest all students in religious life work.
Meetings are to be held every
second and last Monday of each
month. If possible, a prominent
Speaker will be secured for the
first meeting of each month. The
second meeting will be given over
to discussion of the talk of the previous week.
The officers for this year are:
President, Paul Stevens; vicepresident, Kendig Wallace; secretary, Paul Silvester ; treasurer,
Wheeler.
A meeting will be held this
Monday night. The Rev. Dr. William S. Hammond will give a talk
On "John Wesley and His Place
Among the Great Christians."

Shallenberger's Meter-1888

Single-Phase Meter-1921

Oliver B.Shallenberger
T IS ONE THING to produce a new idea
I that is simply of theoretical interest. It is
another to make the new idea into a commercial success.

I

This is the story of Oliver B. Shallenberger,
and how in 1888 he discovered the principle
that led him to invent the watt-hour meter,
the familiar little device that makes practicable
the commercial distribution of alternating current, which means 95% of all the electricity
that is distributed.
Shallenberger, who resigned a Naval commission to take up his work with Westinghouse,
made his discovery while experimenting with
a newly devised alternating current arc lamp.
His attention was attracted by the behavior of
a small spring which had fallen upon the main
magnet of the lamp, into such a position that
the forces proceeding from both the magnet
coil and the extended soft iron core affected it.
And the simple little thing that he noticed was
merely that the spring was slowly rotating! But
to the intelligently curious observer, that was
• enough.
Further experiments having satisfied him that
the action was caused by alternating electric

currents, he set to work, encouraged by his
knowledge of Westinghouse policies, to make
practical the newly found principle. Three weeks
of almost uninterrupted toil, and he had produced the first practical alternating current
meter of the induction type—the universal type
of the present time.
Thus for the first time the measurement of the
quantity of alternating current passing through
a line was made commercially practicable and
its distribution became possible from an economic
as well as an engineering point of view. In fact,
the whole structure of our great power systems
depends upon the accurate measurement, by
millions of such meters, of the electricity used
in the homes and industries of the nation. So
well was Shallenberger's work done, and so
complete was his conception of the possibilities
of his discovery, that for more than thirty years
his fundamental idea has been in use in many
and various forms.
The encouragement which Westinghouse has
always given to new ideas, and the judgment
with which they have been evaluated, are
nowhere better exemplified than in this story of
the alternating current meter.
